marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Legal depositions in the case of Jonathan Beckwith and Younger Helsick v. John Alexander and Gerald Hoose over the estate of Richard Barnes, their father-in-law.
Papers concerning transfer of land by the Basden family and the renting of turpentine forest land; and the will of Erasmus H. Coston.

Early letters discuss crops and the curing of tobacco; many of the letters for 1802-1804 concern the education of his son, Charles, and of John R. Lucas, a student at the University of Edinburgh, Scotland. Topics of interest are: Lucas's recounting of Great Britain's preparation for war during the Napoleonic period; fluctuations of wheat prices; effect of approaching Civil War on price levels; Confederate action near Romney, Virginia, under General T.J. ("Stonewall") Jackson; and lists of commodity prices.
Physician and local politician of Kingston (Rockingham Co.), N.H.

Correspondence containing information on the American Antiquarian Society, local academies, politics, medicine, phrenology, and business affairs. There are also drafts of several letters on theology to the editor of the Universalist Magazine. One of the correspondents was Josiah Butler, U.S. Congressman from New Hampshire, 1817-1823.

Letter from H.H. Forde on the USS WASP to Barlow, recently appointed minister to France. Letter asks Barlow to use his influence to free Forde's brother, who had been taken captive by a French cruiser in 1809 and held without trial.
Nurse and organizer of the American National Red Cross, of Washington, D.C.

Diary and calling cards relating to Miss Barton's travels in Europe in 1869, primarily to Geneva, Switzerland, and Corsica, and to expenses and living conditions there. Includes references to Sir Edward Arnold, editor of the London Daily Telegraph; his wife, Fannie Marie Adelaide Channing Arnold; Thomasina M.A.E. Campbell; and Clarence Horace Upton, U.S. Consul in Geneva.
Washington, D.C. resident, lawyer, and postmaster general.
Correspondence of William Barry, lawyer and postmaster general from 1829-1835. The letters concern Commodore David Porter and changes in the form of the new postal guide.
U.S. naval officer (1812-1861) and Confederate States naval officer (1861-1865).
A routine business letter from "Malvern," near Loretto, Essex County, Va.
William Cole Bayley was the principal assistant engineer for the Manassas Gap Railroad Company in September 1850.
Collection includes statements, receipts, letters, and legal papers related to Bayley's work for the Manassas Gap Railroad Company.
Civil War letters of Confederate soldiers, including a brief description of the Battle of Drewry's Bluff.
Union soldier from Deerfield (Franklin County), Mass.
Letters from a private in the Union Army concerning sickness among troops near Baton Rouge, La., 1862, and giving a graphic description of the Battle of Port Hudson, La., 1863.
Letters from Barnes, a private in the Confederate Army, concerning the defense of Vicksburg in 1863, camp life, rations, crops, and the shooting of deserters.

Chiefly letters (1862 Feb. 7-1864 Nov. 16) to D. Louise Peasley from Theodore H. Barnum of Connecticut. He signed a few letters "Sergeant" in 1862, but by June 1863, he had become a sutler's clerk with the 11th Connecticut Volunteers Regiment. Barnum was located in various places with the regiment in 1863, including Portsmouth and Yorktown, Virginia.

Orders given under Gen. Barton's command at Fredericksburg, Va., to Col. C.J. Philips of the 52nd Georgia Regiment. Topics include depredations on private property and straggling; guards and pickets; and personnel matters.
Engineer; Union Army officer, stationed in Washington, D.C.

Manuscript copy of documents exchanged between Barnard, chief engineer on Grant's staff, and Major General Burnside, July 3-August 6, 1864, relative to mining operations under the Confederate defenses at Petersburg, Va., and the battle of the Crater on July 30; and an extract from a letter by Barnard to his wife, April 2, 1865, reporting on the last days of the siege of Petersburg.
Confederate soldier, from Orange County, Va.
Letters from Barrow, a private in the 61st Virginia Regiment, C.S.A., chiefly concerning his illness and convalescence in the Chimborazo Hospital, Richmond, Va.
Georgia resident (Clarke County), Confederate staff officer, lawyer, and U.S. Senator.

Correspondence of Middleton Barrow, staff officer to Howell Cobb during the Civil War and later a lawyer. He completed the term of Benjamin Harvey Hill in the U.S. Senate. One letter concerns the interests of a divorced woman with certain investments; the other, the Richmond and Danville Railroad.
Sergeant, British Second Battalion Rifle Brigade.

Chiefly a 60-page diary (1899-1902) titled, "Diary of the South African War with General Buller 1899-1902." A journal entry briefly recounts the voyage from Crete to South Africa where Barnett's battalion became part of Sir Redvers Buller's relief column. Other entries describe troop movements to Durban, Newcastle, Ladysmith, and Lydenburg, as well as the march into the Eastern Transvaal after Lord Kitchener's reorganization. Includes also Barnett's army record book, 1895-1903; poetry (some printed); and photographs, primarily relating to the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade.
Letter to Joseph Marshall Stoddard concerning literary matters.
Letters from Mrs. Bartlett concerning the estrangement between herself and her husband, her objections to a divorce, and personal financial matters.
